A noted Johns Hopkins University scientist has revealed his
belief that North America has
been continuously inhabited by
man for at least 100,000 years.
Dr. George F. Carter, nationally recognized "human geographer," is the author of a
book published recently by the
Johns Hopkins Press which reveals that a primitive, very longheaded race of people lived in
Lower California far longer ago
than • was previously thought
possible.
The book, entitled "Pleistocene
Man at San Diego," tells the
story of Dr. Carter's painstaking resehrch, and his findings in
the fields of geology, climatology, and archaeology.
According to the book, Dr.

Carter discovered deeply buried
fire places and crude stone tools
while he was digging near San
Diego, California, and by relating them to changes in climate
and sea level, estimated them to
be approximately 100,000 years
old.
Dr. Carter believes there is a
strong likelihood that the first
Americans were like the primitive people who survived in Lower California into the historic
period.
His discoveries, Dr. Carter believes, will lead to a thorough
revision of the early history of
man in North America.

Although the Jayword's "Fall" issue, which didn't
reach the open market until January 14, attempted, upon
four occasions, to slander the News-Letter, we shall guffaw
at its enfeebled effort, regard it beneath our dignity to
retaliate with unfounded barbs, and instead offer some
constructive criticism.
We might suggest that the editorial board tuck its
collective heads under its clipped wing, and totter back to
the nest; but we do believe that. it can do better. This
issue was "so distasteful that it (wasn't) ... fit for wrapping fish", let alone fowl. Editors, you exhibited a reluctance to flash your own wit, an outrageously poor choice
of jokes and cartoons, and an incapacity to spell, and sightless proof-reading.

of which can be attributed to incompetent typing or mismanagement at the printers (the entire issue incorporated
25 spelling errors). Editor Parkinson exhibited a resplendent array of Spanish terms, only one of which was spelled
zorrectly. Reference to President Eisenhower as "Milty"
was unparalleled in its wit. We rejoiced as the bird
bloated its feathered breast, thus announcing that this
issue was "dirtier" than ever. But we couldn't unearth
one speck ot dirt, other than that some superhuman steelworker ogled once at "a pair of particularly well-formed
breasts." At this we rejoice.
We sugge-st that if the Jayword ever desires to rank
with the most malignine of other campus' humor magazines that it reorganizes. The editors of any such publication should be competent writers and humorists. Their
brainstorms, not solely the works of sundry creative writing students and incompetent cartoonists, should .compose
most of the pages. Jokes should not be antiquated; serious
poetry has no place in a "slightly bigger, tougher and
dirtier Jayword"; articles such as "JAYWORD AWARDS
FOR OUTSTANDING ACHIEVEMENT" are overworked
in high school weeklies.
Tf you want to be dirty, be dirty. A foremost requisite
of an excellent humor magazine editor is a quick wit
coupled with a filthy mind. And we don't mind being
vilified, but, please, spell the News-Letter correctly. Your
record was zero for four last issue.
